Posts.Content: Hi NiceCuppa, So sorry you've had to endure such a thoughtless comment - no you're not super-sensitive, the nurse is insensitive and, like you said, has zero people skills. Also wanted to pick up on your 'constant hindrance' feeling - no, you're not the hindrance, that label belongs to cancer and all the crap that it entails, painful procedures, treatments which, though life-saving, wreak havok with your body and mind - none of this was your choice. Re nursey, in her clumsy way I guess she was making conversation, unaware of the implications of what she had said. No excuse at all, just that she probably didn't mean to harm - doesn't make it any better, and it highlights the inadequacy of proper training at that hospital. A nurse should simply know better than that.  In terms of going back to that hospital, I have seen suggestions on other threads re changing hospitals - don't know if that is an option for you, isn't a possibility for everyone re distances, accessibility etc, but might be worth considering. It's horrible to feel terrified of the place that is supposed to be restoring you to health.  I wonder if it's worth speaking to a nurse on this site? I have only spoken to a work advisor re my phased return to work (bear this in mind for later), and she was very kind and helpful.  Hope someone is supporting you today, sounds like you need a nice cuppa with a good friend.....Hugs, HFxx
Posts.Title: Fuming with comment from nurse in Chemo unit

Posts.Content: Hi Dragonfly46, I've been on Anastrozole (call them 'nasty' tabs) since December so only 2 months but so far so good, I think. I get the odd twinge in my left wrist, difficult to know if it's anything to do with them, but really I seem to be doing fine. I haven't heard of Kisqali, is it another tablet?  Re arm, I have some numbness and sort of inner carpet burn type sensation on the inside of my upper arm and to the side of my armpit, but that's since the sentinel node sampling - nerve damage I think from other posts.  Am sure others who've been on nasties for longer will also pop in before long. HFxx
Posts.Title: Kisqali and Anastrozole

Posts.Content: Hi Tray46, sorry you're going through this turmoil and glad that at least tomorrow you will have a better idea of what lies ahead. Lovely messages already, I just wanted to pick up on the work issue. I had my lumpectomy and node sampling last week of October, did the usual random googling re 'time off for a lumpectomy' and came up with 2 weeks. Duly expected that would be me. After the op, realised the wound was far bigger than a previous lumpectomy for what turned out to be a benign lump, started thinking 2 weeks maybe unrealistic. I wasn't under any pressure except from....ME. Like you, always thinking of others, never off sick, worrying about work. Thankfully I had the sense to post here and lovely ladies swooped in with their stories, so I plucked up the courage to ask for longer. GP signed me off for a further month. Fast forward to eventual oncology appointment, the staff there signed me off for another 2 months to cover radiotherapy. I finished rads last week, am a bit red and sore as well as tired so now do not expect to go back till after half term. Unbelievable, given what I thought at the beginning. BUT I am not skiving, my 'work' is to do my utmost to heal both my body and my mind. I eat well (mostly), go for long walks (mostly) and rest if I need to. I am learning to say no to things I don't want to do or feel won't help me.  Please please give yourself permission to take the time YOU need. We're all different, some folk here have worked through much of their treatment, some because they had to ( I know I'm fortunate in having a supportive employer) and some because they feel that's best for them. Myself, I know I simply have not been ready to go back, physically or emotionally.  Wishing you good luck for tomorrow and sending lots of gentle hugs. HFxx
Posts.Title: DCIS & Masectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Tray46,  That was a horribly long wait for your results, sorry it was not the news you wanted. Not what anyone would choose, but many have gone through it and are here to tell the tale and getting on with their lives again.  Am not surprised it's all a bit surreal, you had such a long build up to this day. Posts.Title: DCIS & Masectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Mazzie5, just caught up with this thread, had a week away and can't believe how much activitiy there was here, managed to keep up with a couple of threads on my phone, but mostly had to wait till bck on a laptop! Just thought I'd wish you well for your rads starting soon, and also add my experience re lifts. As others have said, people cope differently and some work throughout. In my case, I was lucky to be able to be signed off during and after rads, I teach in a special school and it's a very physical job. And the distnces involved would have meant I'd have barely been there anyway. But I know I'm lucky to have that sort of sickness cover. Regarding lifts, I wanted to drive myself for the first week or so, a sort of maintaining independence kind of feeling, but was very happy to accept offers of lifts for the last week, even though I could have driven. The lifts made the later visits more of a social thing, I took the 'driver' for coffee at the hospital cafe and had a couple of stop offs at garden centres on the return journeys. And it was something that friends, who'd offered 'help' at my initial diagnosis time, could actually do. It felt like the nearest thing for any of them to 'share' in my treatment. 3 different friends helped so it spread the load. So my advice would be, take any offers of lifts towards the end, I definitely appreciated the support.  lesleyhelen's aadvice re drinking lots I'd also echo, it's something I'm having to try to watch now I'm back at work (on phased return) as it's tricky to keep up but definitely makes a massive difference. Good whilst on hormone therapy too, with its effects on urinary areas!! Wishing you well for next week! Sooner you start, sooner you'll be ringing the bell! Gentle hugs, HFxx

Posts.Title: WHOSE READY FOR A MEET UP??

Posts.Content: Hi Dakin, and a very warm welcome to this club that none of us really wanted to join. Yes it’s such a shock, a cancer diagnosis, I know I was half expecting it when I found my lump but was still secretly hopeful that it would just be another cyst. Good that you have great support, but hard too as it is so painful seeing your family suffer alongside you. I think that’s where this site comes in, we can share as much or as little as we want, and people here ‘get it’ in a way that is hard for our families and friends to. And sometimes we find we can share more here as we’re not trying to ‘shield ‘ people close to us.  My cancer was also invasive ductal, different receptors so different treatment plan, but similar  old poop in the end! There’s a ‘Triple Negative ‘ group which you may already have found and lots of other triple negative folk in this group. Also threads here for chemo and radiotherapy.  Glad you have found your way here, keep posting and let us know how you get on once it all starts . And feel free to post any questions, no questions are silly here!  Gentle hugs, HFxx
Posts.Title: Diagnosed last week

Posts.Content: Hi Fazzy65, that all sounds very reassuring, good to give it time to sort itself out, now that you know it's not infected. I agree about the shock of the scar, I'd had a previous lumpectomy for what turned out to be a benign fibroadenama, and the scar is tiny, about the length of my thumbnail. Whereas my lumpectomy/ sentinel node sampling scar is the length of my index finger plus the knuckle (I like a real life comparison!) - quite a shocker when I saw it at the first dressing change. Glad all is well, and great they've encouraged you to go back if any concerns, I found the BC nurses very helpful and accessible which was particularly welcome in the early post op days when you just don't know what is 'ok' and 'normal' Happy healing! HFxx

Posts.Title: how long off work after lumpectomy and sentinel node biopsy

Posts.Content: Thanks HClare, it's so helpful to hear this, I don't know where I got the idea that I'd whizz back in after 2 weeks. I think I googled (dangerous) 'recovery after lumpectomy' and something popped up saying 2 weeks. Also, I had a lumpectomy 13 years ago to remove what turned out to be a fibroadenoma and I did recover very quickly, particularly after I got the results and knew it was benign! But this time around is of course completely different and I think I naively just didn't stop to think about how very different - lumpectomy and wide local excision and sentinel node biopsy, all far more invasive than a straightforward lumpectomy. Add the worry about effects of further treatment and the coming to terms with having cancer - totally different ball game.  Anyway I'm so grateful for the replies and encouragement, I've also had 2 lovely emails from managers at work (I am a special needs teacher, hence the moving and handling aspects of my job) completely supporting further time at home. NNxx

Posts.Title: how long off work after lumpectomy and sentinel node biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi Granny59, Thanks for your quick reply and for the hugs! And my team at work have coped fine over the last 2 weeks so there's no reason to hurry back.  You're so right about the treatment plan, I'm really impatient to get the details and dates. At the follow up appointment with the surgeon last week the original diagnosis from the initial biopsy was confirmed, and sentinel lymph nodes were thankfully negative, so it seems I'll have radiotherapy and hormone treatment. But that was all that was said, it's now a wait to hear when I'll see the oncologist, and from then, dates and which hormone treatment I'll be offered. It kind of feels as if it's all lost its momentum, I want that plan! I haven't been able to see my GP yet re extending my sick note, the surgery was a doctor down on friday so only seeing emergencies, but I'll follow it up tomorrow. I found an old thread on this site re going back to work but haven't been able to find it again so thought I'd start this one and get some advice. Thanks and hugs! xxx

Posts.Content: Hi Touche, so sorry that yu still are really none the wiser, such a slow system. I had a similarly tortuous set of investigations 14 years ago - visit to GP, referral, examination at hospital ('a suspicious lump'), mammogram at another hospital, back for results (inconclusive), ultrasound and needle aspiration, further wait for results (atypical cells), core biopsy, another wait (inconclusive), eventually a lumpectomy, wait for results - benign.....Just ridiculous.  Can only echo others' suggestions - keep busy, no googling, try to keep in mind that the majority of lumps and bumps are not cancer. Posts.Title: Appointment tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hi Feb59, and welcome to this lovely online club, lots of support and shared experiences here as well as a great place to rant and rave if necessary! I've been on 'nasty' tabs/ Anastrozole for 2 months, so not that long, but no problems so far. Many ladies here have been on it for much longer, I'm sure some will pop in. I take it after or with my breakfast along with a glass of water and also drink lots throughout the day, a habit I developed in preparation for rads. The only thing I think I've suffered so far is a bit of a twinge now and then in my wrist.  I'm also trying to follow a healthier lifestyle, doing lots of walking as I also worry re the bone thinning effects. Definitely ask for a DEXA scan - I had one mid-January but won't get results till my next oncologist appointment in April unless it shows anything untoward - I'm assuming now that no news is good news as nothing heard.  I don't know the pros and cons of different aromotase inhibitors, I was given Anastrozole following lumpectomy/ sentinel node sampling and alongside 3 weeks of rads in January. But the oncologist did say that if I didn't get on with it I should come back to discuss other options, As I've been fine I've just kept popping the pills! Good luck with your discussions and decisions - I know just what you mean by damned if you do and damned if you don't - all we can do is try to make informed choices as best we can. HFxx

Posts.Title: Still struggling

Posts.Content: Hi Beautiful4 Welcome to the crazy but comforting cancer club, nobody joins willingly but I know I'm very glad it's here.  Am assuming that you've had biopsies done already? In which case hopefully you have more information about your cancer which would help your research. My cancer is also Oestrogen positive and HER2 negative, so ours are similar, but from my very limited experience it's difficult to make generalisations without more details. So mine is Invasive Ductal Carcinoma or IDC but there are lots of other types, some invasive and some non-invasive. Do you know which yours is? Once you do, searching on this site can be very helpful. I've been careful to resist the temptation to google too widely. In my case, I've had the cancer itself removed, good riddance, and will have radiotherapy soon. I've just started on hormone therapy because of the oestrogen positive/ER+  nature of the beast. But this is all to do with my particular case, you really need to know what type, size, grade and stage you have or might have before trying to guess what you might be facing in terms of treatment. Have you been given any idea of a possible treatment plan yet? I'm sure you'll get lots of information and support here, and don't forget to ask, ask, ask questions, I've found the breast cancer nurses very approachable and helpful.  Welcoming hugs, NNxx

Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi all, rainy start but looking more promising, hope we get some decent sunshine. AnnJac you must be heartily sick of this whole dressings/ healing/ not healing business, I feel like shouting 'enough already!!!' on your behalf, but who to? The glimmer of hope, I take it, is the comment 'well granulated'? But 12 weeks is just too long, you must be so longing to get started (and finished) with your radiotherapy but all held up by lack of healing. Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi all, home at last! Love visiting Scotland (my original home) and seeing family and friends but was exhausting! Not helped by being put on 4x daily antibiotics for possible infection (red, swollen apparently hot boob so given penicillin at oncology follow up last week, but at breast clinic today they think it's after effects of radiotherapy - that makes sense to me) - had to be taken on empty stomach so got in the way of tea and scones and generally complicated arrangements. AnnJac, so glad there's finally a plan which sounds like it should sort out your ongoing healing issues - keeping everything crossed for you. And so exciting about the Palace garden party, must be very therapeutic getting ready for such a fab event.  moomy, Henry the puppy is sooooo cute! I bet he's hard work but what a sweet pup! Love the bluebells , Amalie, spotted a few today on a lovely afternoon walk. Also a field full of mums and calves, and a coot on its nest, don't know whether it can be seen as the light wasn't great... Great weather for next few days I think, hope everyone gets to enjoy it in some way. HFxx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi all, fine weather has returned! I prefer this to the hot spell, I love the sunshine but not the heat.  Beautiful photos, moomy, glad you have better weather for this holiday. That wisteria is so pretty Violetsniff, and so well in flower. Where I walked with a friend today, there was a wisteria tunnel which will be fantastic when it is properly in flower but at the moment nothing like as far ahead as yours. And Amalie that soup looks just delicious. AnnJac so sorry you are confined to quarters, it's just been too long, I so hope the graft works and you can get on with your life. You are always so helpful to us all here, it's time things started going right for you. It's so frustrating when you just want to get on with the radiotherapy and get it done, yet are 'stuck' for now until some proper healing begins. Keeping my fingers firmly crossed that next week brings good news. The walk today was lovely, walked out of town to the grounds of a 'stately home', very nice understated and unfussy gardens as well as a rather posh cafe - we sat outside on a bench in the courtyard as we had the dog with us, it was so peaceful and quiet. I guess a Tuesday morning isn't peak time! A couple of slightly 'hairy' moments, firstly when the resident cat appeared, luckily in the distance (dog not keen on small furries) and then when post people arrived (she's also not fond of a high-vis vest or anyone in uniform) but managed to divert her attention each time! The photos are of a dither of ducklings (no idea what the proper collective term is, quite like the sound of a dither) on a little 'lake'and the view from our bench.  Good luck to all getting out for walks or in the garden in this fine weather. HFxx

Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi all, this thread has exploded with activity so I am sure I won't remember half of what I wanted to reply to but here goes.... Firstly, great walking everybody, especially impressed with AnnJac, increasing steps by the thousand, despite all your horrible setbcks - you truly are an inspiration! Also WhatHappened, I remember your posts when you could barely face stepping out and now you're striding out, just shows what determination can achieve. Before I forget, I had a similar experience with getting repeat prescription of Anastrozole, AnnJac - first time, nothing through from hospital so oncology nurse arranged second month supply and I collected it from the hospital pharmacy, could this be possible for you for now? For 3rd month's supply I took the hospital letter to the surgery and they then issued the prescription. I finally saw one of the GPs 2 weeks ago to discuss ongoing issues and phased return to work, this was my first consultation since original referral in September. It seems impossible to make an appointment even weeks in advance, in the end I just went to the daily 'drop-in' clinic where you go on the day and wait (I thought that was meant for emergencies but couldn't see any other way!) My latest repeat prescription I just ordered online, we have that system once it's established. Don't let your tablets run out before you speak to your GP, I'm sure either the hospital or surgery have to arrange your next month's supply one way or another. Leolady56, so sorry you're feeling cast adrift, Sunnyone your comments in response were so apt. I haven't 'got there' yet, it still feels quite early days for me, I think I more feel a bit shell shocked by it all so kind of plod along, not thinking about it too much, haven't really got any idea yet what my new normal is. Hey ho this post is already rather long, sorry if I've rambled on, hope most people have enjoyed today's sunshine one way or another! Hugs to all, HFxx

Sounds like you have the best possible attitude towards it all, and am glad you have such a supportive family.  It's also good for all of us to hear your story, with all its shocks and further shocks, and to hear you talking so positively about it all one year on. Posts.Title: Two cancers, four tumours and a GSOH! Just saying Hello!

Posts.Content: Hi ScienceTeach, sorry you find yourself here, but hopefully you’ll find support and shared experiences, we even manage a few laughs here and there! Of course you’re feeling alarmed and in a panic, it’s frightening to think you might have something sinister lurking in your breast BUT try to remember, most breast lumps and bumps turn out NOT to be cancer. In my own case I’ve been referred many times: ‘nodular’ breasts, duct ectasia, fibroadenoma, cysts.... finally drew the dreaded cancer card last year. Horrible, scary, grim etc but doable. Breast cancer is generally very treatable. And I’ve been back and forth from tests with them saying it’s ok, not ok, atypical cells, suspicious lump - mostly to end up with a harmless diagnosis even after a lumpectomy. Just not this recent time! I’m hoping your  stay here is brief and that your lump joins the majority in being benign - and also remember they must be thorough and do all the tests necessary to establish for sure what the blighter is - but if it turns out otherwise then there’s lots of support here from all sorts of lovely people, you will not be alone.  Keep posting, no questions are silly, and let us know how your story unfolds. Try to stay off Dr Google.... Wishing you well, gentle hugs, HFxx

Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Symptoms

Posts.Content: Hi Lilly012 and welcome to this wonderful (yes really!) online club which none of us would have wanted to join but here we all are, supporting each other, sharing experiences and even having the odd laugh or two.  My breast clinic experiences: referral by GP for 'nodular' breasts at age 21 - no action needed; tearing pain in breast after breastfeeding - duct ectasia - stopped feeding from that breast, no action needed; found lump in my late 40s - needle and core biopsies then lumpectomy - fibroadenoma (harmless); lumpiness in other breast - cysts - left alone; found 'thickening' recently - biopsies showed invasive cancer - lumpectomy and node sampling Oct 18, just finished 3 weeks radiotherapy, on hormone therapy for 5 years. Have the clinic given you any idea what they think at this stage? On the day I had the biopsies, the doctor told me she thought it was cancer; this was confirmed on a follow up appointment to discuss the results. Have you a date for thiss? Sorry for all the questions!  I hope you get the results very soon, the waiting is so hard. You also say it's not the first biopsy you've had so I wonder was the other/s ok? Again apologies for all the questions but the more info you provide, the more likely you'll find someone here with a similar experience. But we all support each other regardless! Wishing you well, keep posting and try not to let the waiting get you down, hugs, NNxx
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Symptoms

Posts.Content: Hi Grandmasgirls, I saw you hadn't had a reply so thought I'd bump it back up - I'm sure someone with a similar diagnosis will soon pop in. Welcome to this online club. None of us would have chosen to join it but hopefully you will find it a great source of support and shared experiences. My type and stage of breast cancer is different to yours so I can't shed much light on your situation, other than to say that you seem to have been waiting a while to have your operation and it doesn't sound like you've had any other treatment in the meantime. It's difficult to speculate as to what else lies in store for you as each person's treatment is tailored to them and their particular type of cancer. I think you should find out more once you've had your lumpectomy (and do ask any questions here about the op - lots of us had them!) and then have your follow up appointment to discuss the post op diagnosis. In the meantime, I don't know if you've already done this, but ther's a group specefically called 'Triple Negative Breast Cancer' (sorry I don't know how to send you a link) - you could post your question there too. And you can also phone the helpline to speak to a Macmillan nurse, sounds like you haven't had much joy at hospital. Wishing you well, do keep posting questions, and keep in touch after your op, gentle hugs, HFxx
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy done

Posts.Content: Hi Emmaj91, Glad you have a date now, hope you can try to forget about it as much as is possible, the waiting is tortuous but sadly nothing can speed it up! I thought I'd pop in re not being able to feel the lump - I think breast lumps come in so many variations and permutations, so there's no 'normal' unfortunately. My own breast clinic referrals started at age 21 when a zealous GP referred me because she thought my breasts were 'nodular' (routine breast exam because I was on the pill) - I couldn't feel anything at all - at that referral the consultant just examined them and said no investigations were necessary. Then whilst breastfeeding over 10 years later I was referred because of tearing pains in one breast - again just an exam, diagnosed with duct ectasia. Years after, I found a lump which turned out to be a benign fibroadenoma after lumpectomy. Then had 'lumpiness' investigated - mammogram followed by ultrasound showed them to be cysts. Finally last October, a lump I found myself was diagnosed as cancer and I've finished active treatment, just popping daily pills for 5-10 years. So I guess I'm trying to say, can't really speculate re your lump because there are just so many different breast conditions (and remember the vast majority are NOT cancer) that you just can't generalise.  We will all be hoping that your visit here will be temporary and that you come back on here after your appointment to say all is well. And whatever happens, there is a wealth of support here for all. Keep posting with any questions or just to have a rant and rave, but also hopefully carry on your life in the meantime and try to put it all to the back of your mind until your clinic date. Love and hugs, HFxx

Posts.Title: Christmas - lonely ? tag me @carolyn28

Posts.Content: Hi AnnJac, sadly I think your question is of the type, how long is a piece of string..... in that there's no universal length of time for any of these things to heal, and some people get more pain/ discomfort than others. I am now 4 months post op (lumpectomy and node sampling so a lesser assault) and still have some issues. My arm mobility is good, but I have noticed at yoga (only started a week ago) that it is no way equal to good arm, either in overall mobility or in ability to ssustain a position. Pain - upper arm next to armpitand just below to the side - a mixture of numbness and like an inner carpet burn, quite weird. And then there's the nipple (my friends now say oh no not the nipple, it makes them cringe!) - it's been super-sensitive since the op and I think worse since rads. I 'blame' most if not all of this on the node sampling - firstly the injecting of the dye which I watched (a bit) on youtube - ugh!!, and secondly the sampling itself, I believe nerves get stretched/ damaged when they're rootling around to locate and extract them. Again, not everybody seems to be affected, and all to varying degrees. And yes agree re timing - generally better in the morning - I think gravity and general dangling doesn't help. A horizontal rest midday ish with arm elevated or at least supported helped in the early days. BUT, big but, I can also feel that it is all getting better as time goes on. Slow progress for some issues but definitely in the right direction. Good enough now that I can walk briskly swinging bad arm more or less normally, which also seems to help, and good enough that I'm off back to work next week (inner shriek). I have discussed all my issues with GP recently, and all seem to be 'normal' and should resolve in time. I have even managed to wear a bra for most of the day today instead of a crop top, for the first time in 5 weeks! I will feel better supported at work in a decent bra, feels too vulnerable in the crop top. So, very long-winded - sorry! - way of saying, I think these things all do lessen, albeit at times painfully slowly. I hope your issues begin to resolve soon AnnJac,you're having a horrible time re wound healing which I'm sure makes all the other pains and discomforts seem even more unbearable. And I'd say keep asking at the clinic re anything that you think is outside the range of 'normal' effects, don't suffer in silence. Gentle hugs, HFxx

Posts.Title: Terrified again

Posts.Content: Hi Emaline, it’s a difficult time (understatement) waiting for surgery, not sure what to expect. As LondonLass has said, it’s hard to predict how you’ll be after the anaesthetic and everyone is different re recovery time. I have had many anaesthetics and am lucky to react well, even feel vaguely euphoric afterwards (I know it’s the drugs!). After some I’ve been back to work 2 days after. My 2 lumpectomies were very different in terms of recovery. The first, for what turned out to be a benign fibroadenoma, was pretty straightforward, and I could have been back at work within a week but it cooincided with half term so I was off for 10 days. The scar was less than an inch. Recent lumpectomy also involved wide local incision (they knew it was cancer) and sentinel node sampling, and the scar is the length of my index finger plus knuckle. A very different beast!! I had expected to be back to work after 2 weeks but was no way ready (my job is very physical) and my GP signed me off for a further month. Then came radiotherapy but that’s another story. So I would say don’t assume anything, be prepared to listen to your body and allow yourself the time you need. Some people are ‘ready’ and better getting back quickly and of course it also depends on your job. Wishing you well for Monday, good to get the op over and done with and you’ll know the nature of your particular beast! Keep posting and let us know how you get on. Hugs, HFxx

Posts.Content: Hi Scaredgirl34 Sorry you're having a worrying time. Re atypical cells - 13 years ago I had investigations into a pea-type breast lump. As part of the testing process I had a needle aspiration and a core biopsy - one of the results came back as 'atypical cells', I can't remember which. The consultant at that time said the results were 'inconclusive' so I had a lumpectomy; when that was analysed it turned out to be a fibroadenoma. Looking back now, I think they must have known or at least suspected that it wasn't cancerous because there was no suggestion of wide local excision or sentinel node sampling (which I've had recently for a new lump which was identified as IDC from biopsies).  Don't know if that helps. I think I'd phone the hospital for a fuller explanation unless you have an appointment coming up? best wishes and hugs, NNxx

Posts.Title: Got my ultrasound back..i have a 4 mm lump with spiculation, have...

Posts.Content: jiw1953, more pieces of the unique jigsaw that is each cancer case. So yours is similar to mine as mine was also Er+ (means receptive to oestrogen hormone) and HER2 negative (means not receptive to HER2 protein or something like that). I don't remember ever being told the Pr status (I think that's to do with being receptive to progestorone?)  In terms of good or bad, I can only say what the doctor said to me which was that Er+ breast cancers respond to oestrogen blocking drugs - in my case I'm on Anastrozole which is one of the drugs used for post-menopausal women. And I'm doing fine on it - so far so good. She said that the HER2 negativeness meant I wouldn't need Herceptin which I think has to be given with chemotherapy? But someone might correct me. The question of chemotherapy, in my case, depended on whether my lymph nodes were affected - they removed the sentinel nodes when I had my lumpectomy and as these nodes were negative, I didn't need chemotherapy or further nodes tested. But because I only had a lumpectomy (for mine, they regarded a mastectomy as 'over-treatment', maybe because it was relatively small and Grade 2?) I was then offered radiotherapy as 'belt and braces' - to increase my chances of not having a recurrence. I finished 3 weeks radiotherapy last Tuesday - not bad at all, I've luckily not had to work during it all and, although I'm tired and a bit sore, it's really been ok. Sorry to be so long-winded, I'm very wary of saying any type is good or bad so have stuck to my own situation which is all I know for sure! Hope you soon have a date for your surgery, I felt so much better once I had a definite start to my treatment. Keep asking questions - there's also an Ask an Expert section here where you can ask questions to nurses and other professionals. Best wishes and hugs, NNxx

Posts.Title: Cancer for a second time

Posts.Content: Hi maggie50, I saw your post hadn't had a lot of response so thought I'd bump it up as someone out there might have had a similar experience and know more about false negatives. Also, welcome to this online club, none of us would have chosen to come here but get lots of support and encouragement as well as a few laughs along the way! Hope your membership is short and you get reassurance from your results but if not you will hopefully find this site a source of friendship and support. In my own limited expereience I had needle biopsy which showed atypical cells followed by a core  biopsy which was inconclusive. So then a lumpectomy which showed thankfully that the lump was harmless (fibroadenoma). That was 13 years ago; more recently I had 'thickening' investigated with core biopsies and this b***** turned out to be cancer so I have had lumpectomy, sentinel node sampling and currently radiotherapy as well as hormone therapy. It's not lovely but it's absolutely manageable and many here cope with all sorts of poopy treatments but come out smiling the other end. Wouldn't want to speculate re your case but just wanted to check that you still have an appointment to get proper feedback from the biopsy? If not then I would definitely get back on the phone for a fuller explanation. Wishing you well, keep posting here it's a great place to rant and rave if necessary, or just to share and compare with others going through similar expereinces. NNxx
